name: Kepler-438
scenarioDescription:
The Kepler-438 Exoplanetary System

Kepler-438 is a star with 0.54 times the mass of the Sun, and 0.52 times its radius. It is located 472.93 light years away from the solar system and is estimated to be 4.4 billion years old, as compared to the Sun which is roughly 4.6 billion years old.

Kepler-438 is known to have 1 exoplanets in orbit around it.

Kepler-438 b

Kepler-438 b was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2015-02. Its semi-major axis is 0.17 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 35.23 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-438.

Its eccentricity, the extent to which the shape of the exoplanet's orbit departs from a perfect circle (Earth's is 0.0167, which is why the shape of Earth's orbit is circular rather than oval in appearance), is 0.03, which means that when Kepler-438 b is at is at its closest point to its host star, 0.16 astronomical units separates the two, and when it is at its farthest point, this number is 0.17. In the case of Earth, these numbers are 0.9832899 and 1.0167103 respectively.

The mass of Kepler-438 b is 1.27 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-438 b is 1.12 that of Earth. At less than 1.5 Earth masses, Kepler-438 b is a regular terrestrial planet, much like the terrestrial planets we find in our solar system, namely Mercury, Venus, Earth and Mars.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system Kepler-438, which contains 1 planets and was discovered by Kepler.
